content: Female Spirituality Shouldn’t Be a Dirty Little Secret Outing myself as a goddess believer Elizabeth Childs Kelly Blocked Unblock Follow Following Jan 23 Credit: Roy Scott/Ikon Images/Getty A bout three years ago, I made a drastic shift in careers: I sold the communications company I founded and began researching and writing about ancient goddess worship . I’ve been trying to explain what I do ever since. It’s not that it’s a terribly complicated subject matter; it’s that the mere suggestion of goddess worship seems to create an awful lot of discomfort for some people. In fact, I’ve gotten quite used to the following exchange—it’s happened in lots of places, but let’s just stage it in the parking lot of my kid’s elementary school for convenience: Person: So, what kind of work do you do? Me: I write about ancient goddess worship and its relevance to our world today. Person: What? Me: Ancient goddess worship. Spiritual traditions that envisioned our source as female rather than male. Person, now with slightly raised eyebrows, glazed eyes, and an artificial smile blooming across their face: Oh. [awkward pause] So, what after-school activities are you signed up for? There could be a lot of reasons for this kind of reaction. Talk of spirituality even in general can make people nervous. Or maybe they’re just not interested. The goddess might not be everyone’s jam, and that’s fine. But there seems to be something particular about linking spirituality and women that makes people supremely uncomfortable. I first became interested in these spiritual traditions after the birth of my second child. Unlike my first go-round at childbirth, I chose to move through this one without medication. Despite the shattering pain that accompanied that decision, it was also a profoundly transcendent moment that left me convinced childbirth might be one of the most spiritual experiences a woman can ever have. I was already a spiritual seeker, albeit a somewhat closeted one at that point, so it’s not surprising that I reached this conclusion. I’d been raised in the Christian tradition, had dabbled in yogic philosophy, and in more recent years, had developed some serious crushes on Buddhism and shamanism. After my son was born, I went back to all the teachings I’d absorbed, looking for some confirmation of the spiritual nature of childbirth. I came up empty-handed. One day, after another fruitless search, a realization hit me like a proverbial thunderbolt out of the heavens: The stories of women’s spiritual experiences don’t exist. Regardless of which spiritual tradition I revisited, the commonality was that the gods were men. Or the disciples were men. Or the teachers and preachers were men. The books I’d read were almost exclusively written by men. All the teachings I’d absorbed before then could not tell me about the profound fullness and sacredness of what it means to give birth because the teachers simply had not experienced it. This realization sent me into a full-on episode of frustrated rage. But once it subsided, I realized I knew better. I didn’t need a book or spiritual tradition to tell me that women were every bit as sacred as men. I could feel it in my bones. I also knew that somewhere in our past, there had to be evidence of strong female deities, and off I went to find them. But that’s where it got tricky. I considered myself a woman of substance. I was a rational thinker with a successful career, and I lived in what I believed was the “real world.” When I began searching for information about goddess traditions, however, I found a whole lot of stuff that scared the hell out of me. My deep and passionate interest in learning about goddess worship felt somehow embarrassing, like a dirty little secret that I needed to keep to myself. There were things called “ goddess oracle cards .” And references to “magick.” And instructions on how to embody divine feminine archetypes to unleash your own inner goddess. I couldn’t put my finger on why, exactly, all of it bothered me so much. It just seemed so unusual and fantastical and so feminine but in the worst possible way. I pictured old women dancing around a bonfire with flowers in their hair and howling at the moon and shuddered at the mere thought. No way. Not for me. I’m grateful that my horizons have expanded tremendously in the last few years, and I’d now consider it an honor to be an old lady dancing around a fire someday, waving my goddess oracle cards proudly in the air. But, back then, my deep and passionate interest in learning about goddess worship felt somehow embarrassing, like a dirty little secret that I needed to keep to myself. My personal experiences at the time seemed to confirm my feelings of shame. Before I left the company I founded, I toyed with the idea of creating a women’s leadership program based on cultivating intuition. I wasn’t very deep into my study of goddess traditions at that point, but I’d learned that our intuition, or inner wisdom, was considered the calling card of the goddess herself. I loved the idea of cultivating our natural gut instinct as a refreshing counterpoint to the business world’s obsession with logic and data and numbers, and I felt that many women could benefit from learning how to better trust their own abilities and ideas—myself included. I liked the idea of an intuitive women’s leadership program enough that I shared it with a successful female executive I was introduced to by a mutual friend. The conversation flowed easily up until the point I mentioned the word “intuition.” She leaned across her desk, lifted her hand, and said, “Let me stop you right there. You cannot use the word ‘intuition’ in the business setting. It’s too ‘woo.’ It sounds like something my immigrant grandmother would talk about.” P retty soon after that encounter, I decided the business world probably wasn’t the best fit for me anymore, and I left it to focus on my research full-time. Since my exit, I’m definitely more likely to meet people who share my enthusiasm for goddess wisdom, and those who do often become my close friends. But I still struggle, not only in those awkward social situations but also in writing about the subject in a way that isn’t completely off-putting. I know I’m not the only one, either. I have several female friends whose work is deeply influenced by their understanding of goddess traditions, but they wouldn’t dream of speaking about it publicly for fear of turning someone off. Even at my yoga studio—a place where alternative thought normally abounds—one of my favorite teachers (a woman) recently introduced an upcoming goddess-themed workshop by saying, “Normally, I’m not into this stuff, but trust me, this one is going to be good.” Why does the idea of female spirituality make people cringe? A veritable mountain of evidence points to the prominence of a feminine form of God in our ancient past. Why is this considered any less significant than our other spiritual traditions? Can we cultivate a vision of women’s spirituality that isn’t bizarre or dangerous but instead deeply beneficial to a world that has been profoundly out of balance for millennia? I have a lot of speculative answers to that last question, but as to our aversion of feminine spirituality, I think it’s deeply connected to a patriarchal system that has taught us that women in general are not only inferior but potentially dangerous. After all, women are responsible for the downfall of humankind as the creation story of the Bible teaches us. In the more recent past, spiritual women were branded as witches—a word that once translated to “healer” in many languages but is now associated with broom-riding and vague practices of evil. Can we cultivate a vision of women’s spirituality that isn’t bizarre or dangerous but instead deeply beneficial to a world that has been profoundly out of balance for millennia? That’s my dream, and I remind myself of it after every awkward encounter about my work. I recently finished writing a book about ancient goddess wisdom and what it has to offer us today—a project two years in the making. The hardest part of the entire manuscript was deciding what to call Her. I cringed every time I wrote the word “goddess” or “divine feminine,” and I kept trying to come up with different words: The DF. Mama D. The feminine face of God (aka The Notorious FFG). I even made up a word: “DiviniShe”—like “divinity” but with a female twist. None of them quite clicked for me. But it seems to me that much of language over time has been limited by patriarchal influence, particularly in how people today often default to thinking of deities as male. We can’t create a new language overnight, and I’m apparently not so great at inventing new words. My best option, then, is to take the words we do have and use them again and again until hopefully their meaning shifts and we can find the inherent beauty in them instead of the strangeness. That’s why, at any point in the near future, you’ll find me on a playground or perhaps at a dinner party speaking earnestly—and perhaps a little awkwardly—about ancient goddess wisdom and why it still matters to anyone who will listen.
title_html: Female Spirituality Shouldn’t Be a Dirty Little Secret
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started

  • Mind
  • Heart
  • Hands
  • Eyes
  • Soul
  • About

Female Spirituality Shouldn’t Be a Dirty Little Secret

Outing myself as a goddess believer

Elizabeth Childs Kelly
Jan 23

About three years ago, I made a drastic shift in careers: I sold the communications company I founded and began researching and writing about ancient goddess worship. I’ve been trying to explain what I do ever since.

It’s not that it’s a terribly complicated subject matter; it’s that the mere suggestion of goddess worship seems to create an awful lot of discomfort for some people. In fact, I’ve gotten quite used to the following exchange—it’s happened in lots of places, but let’s just stage it in the parking lot of my kid’s elementary school for convenience:

Person: So, what kind of work do you do?
Me: I write about ancient goddess worship and its relevance to our world today.
Person: What?
Me: Ancient goddess worship. Spiritual traditions that envisioned our source as female rather than male.
Person, now with slightly raised eyebrows, glazed eyes, and an artificial smile blooming across their face: Oh. [awkward pause] So, what after-school activities are you signed up for?

There could be a lot of reasons for this kind of reaction. Talk of spirituality even in general can make people nervous. Or maybe they’re just not interested. The goddess might not be everyone’s jam, and that’s fine. But there seems to be something particular about linking spirituality and women that makes people supremely uncomfortable.

I first became interested in these spiritual traditions after the birth of my second child. Unlike my first go-round at childbirth, I chose to move through this one without medication. Despite the shattering pain that accompanied that decision, it was also a profoundly transcendent moment that left me convinced childbirth might be one of the most spiritual experiences a woman can ever have.

I was already a spiritual seeker, albeit a somewhat closeted one at that point, so it’s not surprising that I reached this conclusion. I’d been raised in the Christian tradition, had dabbled in yogic philosophy, and in more recent years, had developed some serious crushes on Buddhism and shamanism. After my son was born, I went back to all the teachings I’d absorbed, looking for some confirmation of the spiritual nature of childbirth. I came up empty-handed.

One day, after another fruitless search, a realization hit me like a proverbial thunderbolt out of the heavens: The stories of women’s spiritual experiences don’t exist.

Regardless of which spiritual tradition I revisited, the commonality was that the gods were men. Or the disciples were men. Or the teachers and preachers were men. The books I’d read were almost exclusively written by men. All the teachings I’d absorbed before then could not tell me about the profound fullness and sacredness of what it means to give birth because the teachers simply had not experienced it.

This realization sent me into a full-on episode of frustrated rage. But once it subsided, I realized I knew better. I didn’t need a book or spiritual tradition to tell me that women were every bit as sacred as men. I could feel it in my bones. I also knew that somewhere in our past, there had to be evidence of strong female deities, and off I went to find them.

But that’s where it got tricky. I considered myself a woman of substance. I was a rational thinker with a successful career, and I lived in what I believed was the “real world.” When I began searching for information about goddess traditions, however, I found a whole lot of stuff that scared the hell out of me.

My deep and passionate interest in learning about goddess worship felt somehow embarrassing, like a dirty little secret that I needed to keep to myself.

There were things called “goddess oracle cards.” And references to “magick.” And instructions on how to embody divine feminine archetypes to unleash your own inner goddess.

I couldn’t put my finger on why, exactly, all of it bothered me so much. It just seemed so unusual and fantastical and so feminine but in the worst possible way. I pictured old women dancing around a bonfire with flowers in their hair and howling at the moon and shuddered at the mere thought.

No way. Not for me.

I’m grateful that my horizons have expanded tremendously in the last few years, and I’d now consider it an honor to be an old lady dancing around a fire someday, waving my goddess oracle cards proudly in the air. But, back then, my deep and passionate interest in learning about goddess worship felt somehow embarrassing, like a dirty little secret that I needed to keep to myself.

My personal experiences at the time seemed to confirm my feelings of shame. Before I left the company I founded, I toyed with the idea of creating a women’s leadership program based on cultivating intuition. I wasn’t very deep into my study of goddess traditions at that point, but I’d learned that our intuition, or inner wisdom, was considered the calling card of the goddess herself. I loved the idea of cultivating our natural gut instinct as a refreshing counterpoint to the business world’s obsession with logic and data and numbers, and I felt that many women could benefit from learning how to better trust their own abilities and ideas—myself included.

I liked the idea of an intuitive women’s leadership program enough that I shared it with a successful female executive I was introduced to by a mutual friend. The conversation flowed easily up until the point I mentioned the word “intuition.” She leaned across her desk, lifted her hand, and said, “Let me stop you right there. You cannot use the word ‘intuition’ in the business setting. It’s too ‘woo.’ It sounds like something my immigrant grandmother would talk about.”

Pretty soon after that encounter, I decided the business world probably wasn’t the best fit for me anymore, and I left it to focus on my research full-time. Since my exit, I’m definitely more likely to meet people who share my enthusiasm for goddess wisdom, and those who do often become my close friends. But I still struggle, not only in those awkward social situations but also in writing about the subject in a way that isn’t completely off-putting.

I know I’m not the only one, either. I have several female friends whose work is deeply influenced by their understanding of goddess traditions, but they wouldn’t dream of speaking about it publicly for fear of turning someone off. Even at my yoga studio—a place where alternative thought normally abounds—one of my favorite teachers (a woman) recently introduced an upcoming goddess-themed workshop by saying, “Normally, I’m not into this stuff, but trust me, this one is going to be good.”

Why does the idea of female spirituality make people cringe? A veritable mountain of evidence points to the prominence of a feminine form of God in our ancient past. Why is this considered any less significant than our other spiritual traditions?

Can we cultivate a vision of women’s spirituality that isn’t bizarre or dangerous but instead deeply beneficial to a world that has been profoundly out of balance for millennia?

I have a lot of speculative answers to that last question, but as to our aversion of feminine spirituality, I think it’s deeply connected to a patriarchal system that has taught us that women in general are not only inferior but potentially dangerous. After all, women are responsible for the downfall of humankind as the creation story of the Bible teaches us. In the more recent past, spiritual women were branded as witches—a word that once translated to “healer” in many languages but is now associated with broom-riding and vague practices of evil.

Can we cultivate a vision of women’s spirituality that isn’t bizarre or dangerous but instead deeply beneficial to a world that has been profoundly out of balance for millennia? That’s my dream, and I remind myself of it after every awkward encounter about my work.

I recently finished writing a book about ancient goddess wisdom and what it has to offer us today—a project two years in the making. The hardest part of the entire manuscript was deciding what to call Her. I cringed every time I wrote the word “goddess” or “divine feminine,” and I kept trying to come up with different words: The DF. Mama D. The feminine face of God (aka The Notorious FFG). I even made up a word: “DiviniShe”—like “divinity” but with a female twist.

None of them quite clicked for me. But it seems to me that much of language over time has been limited by patriarchal influence, particularly in how people today often default to thinking of deities as male.

We can’t create a new language overnight, and I’m apparently not so great at inventing new words. My best option, then, is to take the words we do have and use them again and again until hopefully their meaning shifts and we can find the inherent beauty in them instead of the strangeness.

That’s why, at any point in the near future, you’ll find me on a playground or perhaps at a dinner party speaking earnestly—and perhaps a little awkwardly—about ancient goddess wisdom and why it still matters to anyone who will listen.

  • Lifestyle
  • Women
  • Self
  • Soul

    Medium member since Aug 2018

    I write about the intersection of ancient Goddess worship and modern feminism. Join the conversation: https://www.facebook.com/groups/hometoher/

title: Female Spirituality Shouldn’t Be a Dirty Little Secret
content_html:
Female Spirituality Shouldn’t Be a Dirty Little Secret

Outing myself as a goddess believer

Elizabeth Childs Kelly
Jan 23

About three years ago, I made a drastic shift in careers: I sold the communications company I founded and began researching and writing about ancient goddess worship. I’ve been trying to explain what I do ever since.

It’s not that it’s a terribly complicated subject matter; it’s that the mere suggestion of goddess worship seems to create an awful lot of discomfort for some people. In fact, I’ve gotten quite used to the following exchange—it’s happened in lots of places, but let’s just stage it in the parking lot of my kid’s elementary school for convenience:

Person: So, what kind of work do you do?
Me: I write about ancient goddess worship and its relevance to our world today.
Person: What?
Me: Ancient goddess worship. Spiritual traditions that envisioned our source as female rather than male.
Person, now with slightly raised eyebrows, glazed eyes, and an artificial smile blooming across their face: Oh. [awkward pause] So, what after-school activities are you signed up for?

There could be a lot of reasons for this kind of reaction. Talk of spirituality even in general can make people nervous. Or maybe they’re just not interested. The goddess might not be everyone’s jam, and that’s fine. But there seems to be something particular about linking spirituality and women that makes people supremely uncomfortable.

I first became interested in these spiritual traditions after the birth of my second child. Unlike my first go-round at childbirth, I chose to move through this one without medication. Despite the shattering pain that accompanied that decision, it was also a profoundly transcendent moment that left me convinced childbirth might be one of the most spiritual experiences a woman can ever have.

I was already a spiritual seeker, albeit a somewhat closeted one at that point, so it’s not surprising that I reached this conclusion. I’d been raised in the Christian tradition, had dabbled in yogic philosophy, and in more recent years, had developed some serious crushes on Buddhism and shamanism. After my son was born, I went back to all the teachings I’d absorbed, looking for some confirmation of the spiritual nature of childbirth. I came up empty-handed.

One day, after another fruitless search, a realization hit me like a proverbial thunderbolt out of the heavens: The stories of women’s spiritual experiences don’t exist.

Regardless of which spiritual tradition I revisited, the commonality was that the gods were men. Or the disciples were men. Or the teachers and preachers were men. The books I’d read were almost exclusively written by men. All the teachings I’d absorbed before then could not tell me about the profound fullness and sacredness of what it means to give birth because the teachers simply had not experienced it.

This realization sent me into a full-on episode of frustrated rage. But once it subsided, I realized I knew better. I didn’t need a book or spiritual tradition to tell me that women were every bit as sacred as men. I could feel it in my bones. I also knew that somewhere in our past, there had to be evidence of strong female deities, and off I went to find them.

But that’s where it got tricky. I considered myself a woman of substance. I was a rational thinker with a successful career, and I lived in what I believed was the “real world.” When I began searching for information about goddess traditions, however, I found a whole lot of stuff that scared the hell out of me.

My deep and passionate interest in learning about goddess worship felt somehow embarrassing, like a dirty little secret that I needed to keep to myself.

There were things called “goddess oracle cards.” And references to “magick.” And instructions on how to embody divine feminine archetypes to unleash your own inner goddess.

I couldn’t put my finger on why, exactly, all of it bothered me so much. It just seemed so unusual and fantastical and so feminine but in the worst possible way. I pictured old women dancing around a bonfire with flowers in their hair and howling at the moon and shuddered at the mere thought.

No way. Not for me.

I’m grateful that my horizons have expanded tremendously in the last few years, and I’d now consider it an honor to be an old lady dancing around a fire someday, waving my goddess oracle cards proudly in the air. But, back then, my deep and passionate interest in learning about goddess worship felt somehow embarrassing, like a dirty little secret that I needed to keep to myself.

My personal experiences at the time seemed to confirm my feelings of shame. Before I left the company I founded, I toyed with the idea of creating a women’s leadership program based on cultivating intuition. I wasn’t very deep into my study of goddess traditions at that point, but I’d learned that our intuition, or inner wisdom, was considered the calling card of the goddess herself. I loved the idea of cultivating our natural gut instinct as a refreshing counterpoint to the business world’s obsession with logic and data and numbers, and I felt that many women could benefit from learning how to better trust their own abilities and ideas—myself included.

I liked the idea of an intuitive women’s leadership program enough that I shared it with a successful female executive I was introduced to by a mutual friend. The conversation flowed easily up until the point I mentioned the word “intuition.” She leaned across her desk, lifted her hand, and said, “Let me stop you right there. You cannot use the word ‘intuition’ in the business setting. It’s too ‘woo.’ It sounds like something my immigrant grandmother would talk about.”

Pretty soon after that encounter, I decided the business world probably wasn’t the best fit for me anymore, and I left it to focus on my research full-time. Since my exit, I’m definitely more likely to meet people who share my enthusiasm for goddess wisdom, and those who do often become my close friends. But I still struggle, not only in those awkward social situations but also in writing about the subject in a way that isn’t completely off-putting.

I know I’m not the only one, either. I have several female friends whose work is deeply influenced by their understanding of goddess traditions, but they wouldn’t dream of speaking about it publicly for fear of turning someone off. Even at my yoga studio—a place where alternative thought normally abounds—one of my favorite teachers (a woman) recently introduced an upcoming goddess-themed workshop by saying, “Normally, I’m not into this stuff, but trust me, this one is going to be good.”

Why does the idea of female spirituality make people cringe? A veritable mountain of evidence points to the prominence of a feminine form of God in our ancient past. Why is this considered any less significant than our other spiritual traditions?

Can we cultivate a vision of women’s spirituality that isn’t bizarre or dangerous but instead deeply beneficial to a world that has been profoundly out of balance for millennia?

I have a lot of speculative answers to that last question, but as to our aversion of feminine spirituality, I think it’s deeply connected to a patriarchal system that has taught us that women in general are not only inferior but potentially dangerous. After all, women are responsible for the downfall of humankind as the creation story of the Bible teaches us. In the more recent past, spiritual women were branded as witches—a word that once translated to “healer” in many languages but is now associated with broom-riding and vague practices of evil.

Can we cultivate a vision of women’s spirituality that isn’t bizarre or dangerous but instead deeply beneficial to a world that has been profoundly out of balance for millennia? That’s my dream, and I remind myself of it after every awkward encounter about my work.

I recently finished writing a book about ancient goddess wisdom and what it has to offer us today—a project two years in the making. The hardest part of the entire manuscript was deciding what to call Her. I cringed every time I wrote the word “goddess” or “divine feminine,” and I kept trying to come up with different words: The DF. Mama D. The feminine face of God (aka The Notorious FFG). I even made up a word: “DiviniShe”—like “divinity” but with a female twist.

None of them quite clicked for me. But it seems to me that much of language over time has been limited by patriarchal influence, particularly in how people today often default to thinking of deities as male.

We can’t create a new language overnight, and I’m apparently not so great at inventing new words. My best option, then, is to take the words we do have and use them again and again until hopefully their meaning shifts and we can find the inherent beauty in them instead of the strangeness.

That’s why, at any point in the near future, you’ll find me on a playground or perhaps at a dinner party speaking earnestly—and perhaps a little awkwardly—about ancient goddess wisdom and why it still matters to anyone who will listen.
